Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The distribution facility is located at the end of Industry Avenue. The business has operated from this location since 1979, as a responsible contributor to the community.

The company is a member of the National Association of Chemical Distributors dedicated to the code of management practice of the Responsible Distribution Process. The safe management of chemical products is considered priority to minimize the risk to our community, environment, and personnel.

Additionally, Chemsolv(R), Inc. manages the facility in compliance with all Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA), Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Department of Homeland Security (DHS), Virginia Department of Environmental Protection (DEQ) and the United States Department of Transportation (USDOT) regulations.

To ensure the facility continues to operate in a safe and responsible manner in compliance with all regulations, an extensive risk management system has been developed and integrated into our operating procedures.

Significant components of the system include training, operating procedures for chemical handling, inspection, maintenance, emergency response, and incident management. These procedures provided to responsible personnel and management's continual compliance oversight ensures safe chemical management.

The President, Regulatory Affairs Manager, and the Plant Manager are designated as having the primary responsibility and accountability to ensure the plan and all components are in compliance and implemented.



Stationary Source Description and Regulated Substances Handled



The facility is used for receipt, storage, package, and distribution of chemical products.  There is no reactive chemistry conducted at the site.

Both liquid and dry chemicals are received, relabeled, repackaged, bulked, blended, and placed in storage for shipment to industrial, agricultural, government, food, and cosmetic customers.

These packaged containers include pails, drums, totes, and tankers.

The containers are stored in secured areas to prevent accidental damage and in an area away from equipment traffic and chemicals that may, during an incident, contribute to a release from these containers.

Only authorized and trained personnel are permitted to handle the containers.

Aqua Ammonia arrives at the facility by tanker and is repackaged into 55-gal drums or totes. The aqua ammonia is no longer bulked into an above ground storage tank.  The drums are palletized and single or double stacked in an area with limited access away from traffic. 

Isopropylamine arrives at the facility by tanker and is repackaged into 55-gal drums or bulked into a single above ground storage tank. Only senior, experienced operators can work with the isopropylamine. The drums are palletized, single or double stacked in an area with limited access away from traffic, and made to order, no drum storage for stock.

Formaldehyde was removed from the Chemsolv RMP during this update due to it having a vapor pressure less than 10 mm Hg. Formaldehyde does not have a concentration cutoff but is listed with the qualifier "solution".  "According to 40 CFR 68.115, the amount of any listed toxic substance present in a mixture at a concentration greater than 1% does not need to be included in a threshold quantity determination if it can be shown that the partial vapor pressure is < 10 mm Hg" (https://emergencymanagement.zendesk.com).





General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The facility has an aggressive accidental release prevention program that is based upon employee training, chemical safety awareness, equipment and facility management.

Training includes both the classroom environment and observation by management to verify competency. Classes are designed to achieve maximum results within the time period on an annual basis. Knowledge is evaluated by both verbal questioni

ng for some classes during the training and some classes have written tests. Attendance is mandatory for all employees including packagers, maintenance, drivers, and warehouse personnel and verified by both the Regulatory Affairs Manager and the HR Manager. 

New employees are required to receive an extensive orientation to the operating procedures for each phase of the operation including Hazard Communication, Hazardous Material Transportation, Chemicals & Personal Hygiene, Forklift, Personal Protection Equipment, Respiratory Training, Site Security, Emergency Contingency, hazard recognition, Risk Management Program, and safe work practices. Additionally, the operators have specific spill response, clean-up, and emergency response training in the respective Learn to Earn matrix. 

Employees not having worked in a process receive an introduction by thorough procedural documentation review and pairing the employee with a person familiar with the process for an unspecified period. Management within the guidelines of the program verifies competency of safe operating practices.

Maintenance Systems



The program includes an aggressive maintenance and process inspection system to verify all systems are in proper working order and repairs are accomplished promptly to minimize the risk of release from equipment failure.

Qualified and competent operators perform pre and post inspection for the transportation equipment used to move product on the public roads and highways.  Chemsolv maintains the vehicles according to a strict schedule with a strong reputation in transportation equipment maintenance.

All portable tanks, known as tote tanks, are designed for and dedicated to specific products. Each container is inspected before filling using a systematic approach to verify that each and every component is in suitable condition.

Material handling equipment such as fork lifts are inspected daily and each unit receives periodic maintenance according to a schedule. All equipment used in the handling of material are routinely inspected for defects and promptly removed from service when found defective.

The loading and unloading areas for transport vehicles are on concrete surfaces. A release occurring during the loading or unloading of packa

ges can be contained to this area.

Materials stored within buildings are located in areas specific to their hazard class to prevent one group of hazard class from impacting another during an incident.

All buildings are constructed of poured concrete floors to minimize the possibility of a release contacting the ground and impacting the environment. Equipment used in the areas to move containers is designed for their intended use.

Storage areas are routinely inspected according to a schedule to minimize risks associated with improper material storage.

The grounds are secured to prevent unauthorized access to the facility.



Five-year Accident History



Chemsolv has not incurred a reportable incident for aqua ammonia, formaldehyde, or isopropylamine in the 5 years since the last RMP update. Moving forward we will not be reporting on formaldehyde unless it becomes a qualified "solution". This is not to say there have not been any spills, but the loss of product has reduced, policies/procedures have been implemented from root causes from all product spills and most important is that employees are better prepared due to training.



Emergency Response Program



The emergency response program document and procedures were developed when the Environmental Protection Agency enacted the Superfund Amendment and Reauthorization Act known as the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Program or SARA Title III.

This program requires facilities having certain regulated substances in amounts exceeding threshold quantities to notify the Local Emergency Planning Committees (LEPC) and fire departments that would respond to the facility in an emergency of the existence of these substances.

This information is updated annually and made available to the public through the LEPC. Documentation includes the chemical inventory of regulated substances, the container types and storage conditions, maximum amounts at the site during the year, average daily amounts and the number

of days on site.

In addition, site descriptions, drawings of the facility, locations within the facility of each chemical, surface area, equipment locations as well as emergency equipment are included in the documents.

The emergency response and contingency plan developed and coordinated with local responders includes a description of emergency response equipment on site, contacts names and phone numbers, procedures for public notice, guidelines for notifying emergency response agencies and personnel, information gathering forms and methods and reports that must be completed and filed with regulatory agencies.

The emergency response team is 40-hour HAZWOPER certified in response techniques. The program provides training for hazardous incident recognition, personnel protection equipment selection and use, characteristics of hazardous chemicals and the methods for response, cleanup and decontamination.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Plans are continually updated to improve management of chemicals and reduce the risks associated with handling chemical products.

Chemsolv(R), Inc. just initiated a major improvement to its risk management through the implementation of a Chemsolv Safe Work Permits & Preliminary Risk Analysis (PRA) on 9/28/2018 that utilizes a checklist format and consolidates all work permits under one system. It asks the same questions that a thorough job briefing would ask, but in a systematic way by guiding through the major hazards in a checklist form. We review the checklist at the work site and mark which hazards are present. Yellow hazards must be addressed during the completion of the step by step job plan, Red hazards require the completion of the appropriate work permit. The permits are basically additional checklists for the special hazards that are identified. The step by step plan analyzes the work for the hazards of each step.
